My song since being diagnosed is 

In the shadows - the Rasmus  

Here are some of the lyrics 

"In The Shadows"

No sleep
No sleep until I am done with finding the answer
Won't stop
Won't stop before I find a cure for this cancer
Sometimes
I feel like going down and so disconnected
Somehow
I know that I am haunted to be wanted

I've been watching
I've been waiting
In the shadows for my time
I've been searching
I've been living
For tomorrows all my life

I'm very much an Indie girl but one artist I've always loved and one song in Particular.

Lots of pale imitations of this song have come and gone since.........Nina's version will always be the best and is my life anthem. xx

Feeling Good"

Birds flyin' high, you know how I feel
Sun in the sky, you know how I feel
Breeze driftin' on by, you know how I feel
It's a new dawn, it's a new day, it's a new life for me.
Yeah, it's a new dawn, it's a new day, it's a new life for me, ooooooooh...
And I'm feelin' good.

Fish in the sea, you know how I feel
River runnin' free, you know how I feel
Blossom on the tree, you know how I feel
It's a new dawn, it's a new day, it's a new life for me,
And I'm feelin' good

Dragonfly out in the sun, you know what I mean, don't you know,
Butterflies all havin' fun, you know what I mean.
Sleep in peace when day is done: that's what I mean,
And this old world is a new world and a bold world for me...

Stars when you shine, you know how I feel
Scent of the pine, you know how I feel
Yeah, freedom is mine, and I know how I feel..
It's a new dawn, it's a new day, it's a new life for me
[scat]
And I'm feelin'... good.

Posted by Julie1066
24 Jun 2016 8:34 PM

You've made me laugh. I have arthritis and heart problems and had a stroke in 2013, and I'm in a wheelchair. I had my mastectomy on Monday, so I'm sitting here with my drain in.  My song is and always has been Always look on the bright side of life.  Monty python.  Even had it playing as we walked back up the isle, everyone doing a funny dance, unscripted.  The thought makes me smile and keeps me going.  I say let's try anything to help us smile through this fight.  Xx julietta 

Julietta 

Reply
Posted by mistymoley
24 Jun 2016 9:30 PM

Julietta, that reminds me of when we went to my husband's godfather's funeral and on the way out they played Morecambe and Wise, "Bring me Sunshine".  We all left happy, which I'm sure was his intention.  Incidentally, he died of cancer aged 80, but he was with it to the very end. 

Helen

I am not medically qualified, please consult your doctor or undertake your own research.

Posted by LynnMcW
24 Jun 2016 11:39 PM

Julietta, you made me think of what stated this thread "Hey man, I'm alive...!" and that's what we have to be grateful for in this group! I loved thought of you walking back up the aisle to "Always look on the bright side of life"! It reminded me of my friend's dad, taken too soon in his fifties by cancer. He was a biker and the building where the bike club met had a room upstairs. A group of women line dancers asked if they could rent the room for their rehearsals and the two groups became friends. When my friend's dad died they had a service at the crematorium which ended with 12 hairy ar$ed bikers doing a line dance to "Cotton Eye Joe" along the aisle of the crematorium!

Posted by moomy
29 Jun 2016 5:32 PM

I Have to confess here.....

I love classical music, always have, but with our lass being a professional musician, sometimes I felt very afraid and emotional with music playing. I sing, too, so refused to allow myself to 'think'  while I was singing any music I loved (you can NOT sing and cry!) while daughter was failing so many treatments. I stopped listening but never really quite stopped singing. 

Now I'm beginning to enjoy music again, all over again! Going to watch Saint-Saens' Organ Symphony in a concert on Saturday (but that always brought me to tears, so tissues will be needed!) 

Hugs xxx

Ps, hope you'll forgive, just noticed this is a breast cancer thread! 

Moomy

Posts.Title: Anthem

Posts.Content: A great mention for you lovely lot in the breast group! From today's Telegraph: Cancer is terrifying - but it doesn't have to be lonely, believe me I also found new friends by stumbling onto Macmillan Cancer Support’s online community, a forum which is open 24 hours a day where you can share experiences with others in the same situation. The ladies on there were amazing and offered so much helpful advice. We compared notes about chemo and how to deal with a mastectomy. These were invaluable to me - and would be a lifeline to someone who doesn't have friends or family close by.
Posts.Title: The Macmillan Community - invaluable and a lifeline...

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz there is some information about Tamoxifen on the Macmillan site - there's a section on side effects. You could also call the Macmillan Support Line on 0808 808 0000 (Mon-Fri, 9am to 8pm) for some expert advice/information. M.

Ugh! So now it's all over Facebook with people congratulating each other for shaving! "You're so brave to shave your hair off" over and over again.

I would consider shaving my hair now to be an absolute doddle. Chemo, surgery. radiotherapy, herceptin, letrozole, unwanted menopause with no hope of HRT. Go on then, I dare you!

I've hidden the ad.

Not Macmillan's most sensitive so let's hope it surpasses all previous campaigns and brings in millions.

Posted by Hevbojangles

Absolutely agree on both counts.  And  some women look okay after mastectomy and reconstruction.   If I had known  before treatment that my surgeon would do such a brilliant job, I wouldn't have gone through so much turmoil about my op. My reconstructed left tit looks pretty good.  It would be helpful to newbies to see that they can look okay .It'll never be the same as a proper breast, but that's the price we have to pay.  And I'm okay with it. Mostly.

Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Judy, That's an interesting suggestion and we're open to discussion. Could you give us some ideas as to what form you would like your feedback to take?
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, and thank you again for all the feedback. I recognise the depth of feeling about the Brave the Shave campaign, but I’m not sure where to start with any replies - there are a lot of issues and questions here about fundraising, our campaigns and other related issues.  As the Online Community team we can’t address questions about the Brave the Shave campaign as well or as quickly as other teams working at Macmillan. We run a peer support community and our focus is on helping people affected by cancer with emotional and practical support. If you want to go through a more appropriate channel, I’d encourage you to fill in our complaints form to make your complaints official. This will make sure that the correct procedure is followed and that all complaints to Macmillan are logged. Kind regards, M.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Kacang - good idea! Here's the link to more info about the Cancer Voices scheme.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hello and thanks to everyone who is commenting in this thread. Please be assured that you have a direct line to Macmillan - we're passing all your comments on to the Brave the Shave team. I'll post more tomorrow and try to explain our approach to the this year's fundraising campaign. M.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I passed all your comments on to the Macmillan team working on Brave the Shave and asked for a response and some background - which I'm posting here. == Thank you for your comments about this year's Brave the Shave campaign. It's really important for us to understand how this campaign is perceived, so we thank you for commenting. I'd like to reassure you that all the feedback we receive is reviewed and is used to shape future campaigns. At the beginning of the year, we spoke to more than 770 people who support cancer charities and  who have had a loved one who had been diagnosed with cancer. We captured their thoughts and feelings about a range of images and wording so that we could truly understand their response to this campaign. We used this to shape Brave the Shave this year. It is also important that we understand why it is that so many people are keen to shave their heads to raise money for Macmillan. £7.1m was raised last year alone by people who took part and this money is vital in helping us support more people affected by cancer. We found that more than half of people who signed up last year did so because someone close to them has been affected by cancer and they wanted to do something to show their support. We understand that it's not something that everyone would feel compelled to do, but we want to support the people who Brave the Shave as an act of solidarity and a way of giving back to Macmillan. This year's campaign focuses on the personal and powerful reasons that people have for taking part, so that their stories can be heard. We want to be very clear that in no way do we believe or imply that shaving your head for charity and losing your hair due to cancer treatment are comparable experiences. It’s not our intention in any way to compare the two experiences and we will continue to take on board any feedback we receive to make sure that our campaigns and events are as sensitive as possible.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Our case studies team enjoy keeping us on our toes with ever more hard to fulfil requests for stories - and I think you'll agree, this is one of the toughest, but I promised that we'd give it a go... Do you know of any mums who have given birth this year after having chemo when they were pregnant? The Sun are looking to do a nice shoot and interview in London for the health section. They will cover travel expenses. It will be a ‘our first Christmas’ feature.  If this sounds like you, someone you know or someone who is on the community then please contact us via stories@macmillan.org.uk Many thanks in advance, M.
Posts.Title: First Xmas with baby after having chemo

Posts.Content: Here you go Lee - community.macmillan.org.uk/.../102578 The Room is another group/area on the forum - where people can let off steam.
Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: I'll edit some of the contributions in this discussion to remove some of the more personally directed comments. This is an open discussion and everyone is welcome to contribute.  Here is a relevant section from our Community Guidelines: We ask you to be tolerant and respectful of other members’ beliefs and opinions at all times. We understand that people often have strong feelings about the topics addressed in this community however, personal attacks are never justified. We may remove any comments others find offensive or threatening or which are deemed to be escalating a situation. We may also remove an entire thread if a strong disagreement develops. It is your right to disagree with an opinion, but do not attack the person or people who hold it and please make your point respectfully. If someone posts something you feel violates our Community guidelines please let us know immediately by using the alert moderator link (beneath every post), and then ignore it. Please do not confront members publicly, just report and ignore. Thanks, Michael.

Posts.Content: While we're waiting - I've just posted this over on the chat thread... Women Who Are Going Through Chemo Are Decorating Their Eyebrows For The Festive Season [from the Younger Breast Cancer Network over on Facebook] Merry Christmas everybody.
Posts.Title: Missing Avent Calendar

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, There's a topic about stress and anxiety here - some of the advice might be useful for you. We also have an article - Focusing on your well-being. And it may help you to have a chat to one of the advisers on the Macmillan Support Line - on 0808 808 0000 (calls are free and it's open today until 5pm) We have an article on getting support over Christmas here. Best wishes, M.
Posts.Title: How can I stop myself crying?

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy, I'm so sorry that you're going through this. The main thing to do is to get some independent legal advice, either from a law centre or the CAB. Here are the numbers for the Shelter helpline: Call Civil Legal Advice on 0345 345 4345 for free legal advice, if you are eligible for legal aid.  Call Shelter's helpline on 0808 800 4444 if you have nowhere to stay right now. And here is a link to the Shelter website. Please do give Shelter a call for some specialist housing advice - the lead story on their website is about getting cancer and being in threat of losing your home. You could also consider reporting the fake person to the police, trading standards and the local authority. If you need additional support from a local group there's a page called In Your Area here. I'd also strongly recommend trying the Macmillan Support Line once again - and ask to speak to a benefits advisor. The number is 0808 808 0000 (Mon-Fri, 9am-8pm). We also have an open, Ask the Expert thread here - where you can post a question to one of our benefits advisers. Kind regards, M.

Posts.Title: HOPE COURSE !

Posts.Content: Hi MrsB, It sounds like you are having an awful time and I just wanted you to know that someone had read your post and is thinking of you. I'm afraid that we can't give medical advice on here so I would strongly recommend that you call the Macmillan Support Line on Monday the number is 0808 808 0000. In the meantime, I'm sure someone will be along to offer support and reassurance soon.  You could also post a message in the Breast Cancer group - I mention this because it's a busier area of the site and you may get more replies. I'd also like to quote the wise words of our Community Champion, Dreamthief, 'Please don't google too much looking for information as a lot of stuff out there is very out of date or worryingly misleading, so stick with reputable sites like here, Cancer Research uk (CRUK) and the NHS.' Kind regards, Michael. [edit - moved this topic to the Breast Cancer group as requested]
Posts.Title: Utterly terrified.

Posts.Content: Just to address these points: It is entirely inappropriate for people to be promoting alternative treatments on an organisation that is backed and funded by the UK government from a research perspective that does not include alternative therapies.  I think you and MCM should be much better at taking a position on this. Here is some information about how Macmillan raises and spends charitable money. And here is the Macmillan position on alternative therapies: Alternative therapies are treatments that are used instead of conventional medical treatment. They are often confused with complementary therapies. Complementary therapies are treatments that are taken with conventional treatment. Many alternative therapies claim to actively treat or even cure cancer. But there is no scientific proof to show this. No alternative therapies have ever been proven to cure cancer or slow its growth. Some people seek alternative therapies because having unpleasant side effects from conventional therapies may be frightening. However many people with early cancer can be cured with conventional medical treatments. Doctors usually advise against using alternative therapies because alternative therapies have not been tested in the same way as conventional treatments. Although some alternative therapies may do no harm, others can be very harmful and may affect how well conventional treatment works. Always speak to your doctor before making a decision about alternative therapies. You can also call our cancer support specialists. you can read more information about alternative therapies here. Here is some detail about our approach to moderation of alternative therapies: When discussing alternative therapies, please do not: • Advocate the use of any alternative therapy • Claim that any alternative therapy can cure cancer, reduce the size of tumours or in any way treat cancer • Advise anyone to ignore medical experts’ advice on the use of any treatment whatsoever • Promote any alternative therapy. Macmillan is dedicated to providing high quality, expertly developed information about cancer, we have a duty to try to ensure that the information shared by our members on this site does not mislead our readers or cause them harm. All of our cancer information undergoes a rigorous editing process to ensure that it is factually accurate, so we can’t allow any mention of treatments or therapies which are still unverified, and illegal in some cases. The main reason is that some of the information which is posted could be really worrying for someone who is themselves, or has a family member who is currently undergoing conventional treatment for cancer. I hope that this helps. M.
Posts.Title: Dangerous internet information
